docs.lead_paragraph: The rabbi at the center of a scheme that funneled millions of public school dollars from a Brooklyn district to a Jewish girls' school said yesterday that he knew dozens of Hasidic housewives were collecting paychecks and insurance benefits for no-show jobs, but that he justified the arrangement in his own mind because he believed it benefited the children who attended his school. ''You're right to say, 'The end justifies the means,' '' the rabbi, Hertz Frankel, said yesterday, in his first interview since pleading guilty on April 9 to one count of conspiracy in the 20-year scheme. The rabbi's comments came as investigators, and the rabbi himself, shed new light on how a criminal operation of such magnitude had gone undetected for so many years.

headline.main: After Guilty Plea, Rabbi Explains Actions in a Fund Diversion Scheme

docs.lead_paragraph: It was an elaborate scheme that somehow went undetected for nearly two decades, investigators said yesterday: a prominent Hasidic rabbi and a Brooklyn public school district conspired to place dozens of Hasidic housewives in no-show jobs on the district payroll as part of a plot to siphon more than $6 million to a private Jewish girls' school and its affiliates. The women got health insurance benefits for their families -- some with as many as 10 children -- but often handed their paychecks over to the rabbi, Hertz Frankel, investigators said. The rabbi gave most of the money to the school, Beth Rachel, in Williamsburg, which bills itself as the largest Jewish girls' school in the world.

docs.lead_paragraph: The Women's National Basketball Association and its players union reached an agreement in principle yesterday on a new four-year contract, managing to negotiate differences that had once threatened to delay the start of the season. If ratified, the collective bargaining agreement will be the first for the women's pro league and, according to league officials, the first of its kind for women's team sports. The league's 122 players are expected to vote on the proposal by April 22 for a season that runs from June to August.

Sweeney, the A.F.L.-C.I.O.'s president, it was a perfect homecoming -- the New York janitors' union he long headed held one of the city's most spirited labor demonstrations in years yesterday as 5,000 union members rallied at the Port Authority midtown bus terminal to protest the use of nonunion janitors. Beginning in Bryant Park, thousands of union members, often shouting and blowing whistles, marched two blocks west to the bus terminal, where they denounced Laro Service Systems, the contractor responsible for cleaning the terminal.

docs.lead_paragraph: George Soros, the billionaire financier, plans to spend $15 million on a new program to de-emphasize profit in medical care, develop altruistic service programs for young doctors and encourage consumer groups to join with physicians to monitor the quality of care better. Mr. Soros said the money would pay for research and lectures from scholars on the role of professionalism and ethics in modern medicine, and help develop programs for young doctors to learn how to provide medical services to patients outside of the medical mainstream, like new immigrants or the homeless. The program will also solicit grant applications from groups hoping to form physician-patient alliances to help define priorities in care.

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: An April 11 editorial supports New York Attorney General Eliot L. Spitzer's proposal to order certain high-risk psychiatric patients to follow their outpatient treatment programs or face hospitalization. Yet managed care would neutralize any benefits from this reform. Insurance typically covers only four medication-management sessions a year, each lasting 10 minutes. If the patient refuses outpatient care and is ordered to a psychiatric hospital, managed care rarely allows more than a week's stay.

docs.lead_paragraph: A deep financial crisis is spreading like a virus through the nation's teaching hospitals. It is undermining their honorable and historic mission, which has been to train new generations of physicians, to conduct critically important medical research and to provide treatment for, among others, the poor. A devastating combination of financial pressures ''has produced a situation in which our best hospitals are now essentially all losing money,'' said Dr. Joseph Martin, dean of the Harvard Medical School. He was referring to hospitals in the Boston area, but similar pressures are being felt at teaching hospitals across the country.
